messages.content:
Give me two options with different firmness. This is about a harsh message and I want to de-escalate the tone with a friend. Use a quick note. Match a best_friend tone while staying direct.
Constraint: be firm but respectful. Outcome: keep things constructive.
Original line: "Can you stop sending new tasks after 10pm?"

Thanks for the context. I will remove extra heat and keep the signal. Here is a draft: Hi a friend - quick reset on a harsh message so we can stay aligned. My request is to put the ask in one clear sentence so we can keep things constructive. Do you want a softer or firmer variant?

Help me draft it. I need to correct a misunderstanding about feedback that landed badly with a client over email. Please aim for a professional tone that still lands.
Context: I already flagged it once.
Constraint: stay factual. Outcome: stop the pattern.
Original line: "We need a single owner for this."

I can help with that. I will anchor it in what you need next. Try this: Hi a client - I want to address feedback that landed badly so we can work better together. Can we agree to flag urgent items explicitly? It keeps stop the pattern. I can also make a version that is more direct if needed.

Give me two options with different firmness. I am trying to follow up without sounding pushy regarding a request I cannot take on. It is for a friend in a project update. Keep the tone family and steady.
Context: I want to fix it without drama.
Constraint: sound confident. Outcome: protect the relationship.

Got it. I will keep it short and keep the boundary clear. I will shape it to be family, but still sound confident. Try this: Hi a friend - naming a request I cannot take on directly so we can fix it fast. Could we reduce interruptions during focus blocks? That will help protect the relationship. I can also make a version that is more direct if needed.

Give me two options with different firmness. The topic is a scheduling conflict. I need to give direct feedback to my sibling via email. Keep the tone family and steady.
Context: the goal is to keep things constructive.
Constraint: avoid passive-aggressive wording. Outcome: move the work forward.

We can keep it direct and steady. I will keep it family and avoid passive-aggressive wording. Draft: Hi my sibling - quick reset on a scheduling conflict so we can stay aligned. Can we confirm priority and deadline before work starts? It will help move the work forward. Do you want a softer or firmer variant?

Give me two options with different firmness. This is about a request without a deadline and I want to decline politely with a roommate. Use a quick note. I want it to sound friendly without being vague.
Context: I already flagged it once.
Original line: "This keeps changing and I cannot plan around it."
Constraint: use plain language.

Got it. I will keep it friendly and use plain language. Here is a draft: Hi a roommate - I want to address a request without a deadline so we can work better together. My request is to put the ask in one clear sentence so we can reduce confusion. If you want, I can give two variants with different firmness.

Rewrite my line. I am trying to set a clear boundary regarding scope creep. It is for my manager in a review comment. Match a friendly tone while staying direct.
Constraint: keep it short. Outcome: move the work forward.
Original line: "This keeps changing and I cannot plan around it."

That makes sense. I will shape it to be friendly, but still keep it short. Draft: Hi my manager - I want to keep this constructive and clear about scope creep. Can we agree to confirm what done looks like? It keeps move the work forward. I can also make a version that is more direct if needed.

Make it land without sounding cold. I need to apologize without over-apologizing about a request I cannot take on with my sibling over a project update. Please aim for a best_friend tone that still lands.
Context: I need a version I can send today.
Constraint: be firm but respectful. Outcome: set a repeatable norm.
Original line: "I am confused about the priority and the deadline."

Got it. I will keep it short and keep the boundary clear. Draft: Hi my sibling - I want to be clear about a request I cannot take on and what I need next. Can we batch changes into one update? It will help set a repeatable norm. Do you want a shorter version for a project update?

Help me draft it. I am trying to request a change in behavior regarding a harsh message. It is for my manager in a status message. Keep the tone family and steady.
Context: this is slowing the whole project down.
Constraint: avoid blame. Outcome: align on priorities.
Original line: "I cannot take this on without dropping something else."

Got it. I will keep the request specific and easy to follow. Try this: Hi my manager - I want to address a harsh message so we can work better together. Can we agree to keep new requests inside work hours? It keeps align on priorities. I can also make a version that is more direct if needed.

Tell me what to say. I need to request a change in behavior about a harsh message with my sibling over chat. Match a family tone while staying direct.
Context: I want to fix it without drama.
Original line: "We need a single owner for this."
Constraint: be firm but respectful.

Got it. I will remove extra heat and keep the signal. I will aim for a family tone and keep it be firm but respectful. Try this: Hi my sibling - I want to keep this constructive and clear about a harsh message. Could we avoid rewriting without a quick heads-up? That will help make the decision clear. Do you want a softer or firmer variant?

Give me two options with different firmness. I am trying to give direct feedback regarding missed deadlines. It is for a teammate in a quick note. Make it friendly but still clear.
Context: I want to fix it without drama.
Original line: "Can you stop sending new tasks after 10pm?"
Constraint: avoid passive-aggressive wording.

Thanks for the context. I will anchor it in what you need next. I will keep it friendly and avoid passive-aggressive wording. Here is a draft: Hi a teammate - I want to keep this constructive and clear about missed deadlines. My request is to reduce interruptions during focus blocks so we can protect the relationship. Want me to make it even tighter or more empathetic?

Keep it tight and usable. This is about unclear ownership and I want to request a change in behavior with my coworker. Use a review comment. Keep the tone serious and steady.
Constraint: be firm but respectful. Outcome: avoid another escalation.
Original line: "Please do not rewrite my work without telling me."

We can keep it direct and steady. I will keep the request specific and easy to follow. Try this: Hi my coworker - naming unclear ownership directly so we can fix it fast. My request is to avoid rewriting without a quick heads-up so we can avoid another escalation. Do you want a softer or firmer variant?

Make it clear and low-drama. I need to follow up without sounding pushy about a plan that keeps changing with a client over a meeting follow-up. Make it serious but still clear.
Constraint: keep it to one or two sentences. Outcome: avoid another escalation.
Original line: "The last message felt harsh and I want to reset."

That makes sense. I will keep it serious and keep it to one or two sentences. I will remove extra heat and keep the signal. Try this: Hi a client - naming a plan that keeps changing directly so we can fix it fast. I would like us to reduce interruptions during focus blocks. It supports avoid another escalation. Want me to make it even tighter or more empathetic?

Tell me what to say. This is about feedback that landed badly and I want to apologize without over-apologizing with a group chat. Use chat. Make it best_friend but still clear.
Context: it has happened three times this week.
Constraint: stay factual. Outcome: get agreement on next steps.

That makes sense. I will aim for a best_friend tone and keep it stay factual. Draft: Hi a group chat - I want to keep this constructive and clear about feedback that landed badly. Can we agree to put the ask in one clear sentence? It keeps get agreement on next steps. Do you want a softer or firmer variant?

Help me draft it. The topic is missed deadlines. I need to follow up without sounding pushy to my partner via chat. Please aim for a professional tone that still lands.
Context: I want to be accountable and clear.
Original line: "The last message felt harsh and I want to reset."
Constraint: be gentle but clear.

We can make this clear without being harsh. I will keep the tone professional while staying be gentle but clear. I will focus on actions and requests, not blame. Sendable version: Hi my partner - I want to address missed deadlines so we can work better together. My request is to confirm priority and deadline before work starts so we can protect the relationship. I can also make a version that is more direct if needed.

Give me two options with different firmness. This is about too much context switching and I want to set a clear boundary with a friend. Use text. I want it to sound serious without being vague.
Constraint: sound calm. Outcome: get agreement on next steps.
Original line: "Can you stop sending new tasks after 10pm?"

We can keep it direct and steady. I will shape it to be serious, but still sound calm. Sendable version: Hi a friend - naming too much context switching directly so we can fix it fast. Can we agree to avoid rewriting without a quick heads-up? It keeps get agreement on next steps. Do you want a shorter version for text?

Rewrite my line. The topic is a scheduling conflict. I need to reset expectations to a professor via a status message. Make it friendly but still clear.
Constraint: keep it short. Outcome: move the work forward.
Original line: "I want to help, but the request is too vague."

I can help with that. I will shape it to be friendly, but still keep it short. I will keep it short and keep the boundary clear. Here is a draft: Hi a professor - naming a scheduling conflict directly so we can fix it fast. Can we confirm what done looks like? It will help move the work forward. Do you want a softer or firmer variant?

Help me draft it. I need to set a clear boundary about scope creep with a client over chat. I want it to sound friendly without being vague.
Context: I want to fix it without drama.
Constraint: sound confident. Outcome: avoid another escalation.

Understood. I will anchor it in what you need next. Try this: Hi a client - I want to be clear about scope creep and what I need next. Can we batch changes into one update? It will help avoid another escalation. Do you want a softer or firmer variant?

Tell me what to say. This is about a decision that was reversed and I want to correct a misunderstanding with my partner. Use email. I want it to sound serious without being vague.
Constraint: stay factual. Outcome: stop the pattern.
Original line: "I need you to confirm the deadline before I start."

We can keep it direct and steady. I will shape it to be serious, but still stay factual. Draft: Hi my partner - naming a decision that was reversed directly so we can fix it fast. I would like us to avoid rewriting without a quick heads-up. It supports stop the pattern. Do you want a softer or firmer variant?
